layer_3.title: Column Picture: Linear Combinations in 3D Space
Question: Can Ax = b be solved for every b?
Matrix-vector multiplication as linear combination of columns

detailed_breakdown.detail: Introduction to MIT course 18.06, Linear Algebra; Instructor introduction; Course textbook and web page details mentioned.
Statement of the fundamental problem: solving a system of linear equations.  Focus on the case of n equations and n unknowns.
Introduction of a 2x2 system of linear equations: 2x - y = 0 and -x + 2y = 3.  The matrix form Ax = b is introduced: A = [[2, -1], [-1, 2]], x = [x, y], b = [0, 3].

Row picture explanation begins with the first equation, 2x - y = 0. Graphing this equation in the xy-plane, identifying points (0,0) and (1,2) that satisfy the equation and illustrating the line of solutions.
Graphing the second equation, -x + 2y = 3. Identifying points (-3,0) and (-1,1) and drawing the line. Emphasis on the fact that this line does not pass through the origin.
The solution is identified as the intersection point of the two lines. The coordinates (1,2) are verified as the solution to both equations.
Introduction to the column picture.  The matrix equation Ax = b is rewritten to highlight the columns of A: x[2,-1] + y[-1,2] = [0,3].
Definition of a linear combination of vectors.  This is emphasized as a fundamental operation in linear algebra.
Geometric interpretation of linear combinations.  The columns of A are plotted as vectors in the xy-plane. The solution is visualized as a combination of these vectors.
The solution (x=1, y=2) is confirmed geometrically. The linear combination 1*[2,-1] + 2*[-1,2] = [0,3] is shown visually.
Introduction of a 3x3 system of linear equations: 2x - y = 0, -x + 2y - z = -1, -3y + 4z = 4.  The matrix form Ax = b is presented.
Row picture in three dimensions.  Each equation represents a plane. The solution is the intersection point of the three planes. The difficulty of visualizing this in 3D is acknowledged.
Column picture in three dimensions. The columns of the matrix are viewed as vectors in 3D space. The problem is to find a linear combination of these vectors that equals the right-hand side b.
The solution (0,0,1) is identified because the right-hand side is equal to the third column. This solution is connected to the row picture as the intersection of three planes.
Transition to a discussion about solvability.  The question posed is: Can we solve Ax = b for every possible vector b?
The solvability question is rephrased in terms of linear combinations: Do the linear combinations of the columns fill the entire three-dimensional space?
Introduction of the terms 'non-singular' and 'invertible' matrices.  These are the matrices for which Ax = b is solvable for every b.

Discussion of when a system may not have a solution for every b.  This occurs when the columns of A are linearly dependent, meaning they lie in the same plane (or lower dimensional subspace in higher dimensions).
Extension to higher dimensions. The example considers a 9x9 system, with nine vectors in nine-dimensional space.
The difficulty of visualizing these higher-dimensional spaces is discussed.  The lecturer states that we 'pretend' to visualize the spaces.
Linear combinations in nine-dimensional space.  The central idea of linear algebra is presented as understanding linear combinations of vectors in high-dimensional space.

Discussion of linear dependence of columns in higher dimensions.  If columns are dependent, the linear combinations do not fill the entire space.  The concept of an eight-dimensional plane within nine-dimensional space is introduced.
Matrix-vector multiplication is revisited. Example matrix: [[2, 5], [1, 3]]; vector: [1, 2].
Column-wise multiplication: the result is obtained by taking one times the first column plus two times the second column. Result: [12, 7].
Row-wise multiplication (dot product): the result is obtained by computing the dot product of each row with the vector. Result: [12, 7].
Emphasis that matrix-vector multiplication is equivalent to a linear combination of columns of the matrix.
Summary of the lecture's content for 2x2 and 3x3 systems, focusing on row and column pictures.
Transition to the next lecture which will focus on the elimination method for solving linear systems of any size. Also previews the discussion of when there isn't a solution.
